byline.contributor: Monica Davey contributed reporting from Chicago.

abstract: Wisconsin Gov Scott Walker has abandoned some of his trademarks as he campaigns in early primary states in advance of probable 2016 presidential run, most notably his Upper Midwest accent; is tailoring case for his nomination to audiences, and may be Republican under most pressure to show that he can translate home-state popularity into credible national campaign.
lead_paragraph: The governor of Wisconsin has filtered out his regional accent, cut down rambling in speeches and started dressing to please on visits to states like New Hampshire.

headline.main: For 2016 Run, Scott Walker Washes ‘Wiscahnsin’ Out of His Mouth
headline.print_headline: For 2016 Run, Walker Washes ‘Wiscahnsin’ Out of His Mouth

snippet: The governor of Wisconsin has filtered out his regional accent, cut down rambling in speeches and started dressing to please on visits to states like New Hampshire.
